metadata.case_name: K. C. Nayar v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioner is a trained machineman employed in Central Tractor Organisation from 13-5-1948.

Petitioner continued in government service and rendered good account until services terminated by office order No. 375 dated September 16, 1954: 'Shri K. C. Nayar... is informed that his services are no longer required... terminated with immediate effect... one month's pay in lieu under Rule 5 of Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.'
Petitioner's appeal against termination rejected on December 6, 1954 (Annexure B).
Petitioner obtained service certificate: Served as Machineman from 13-5-1948 to 21-9-1954, terminated under Rule 5.
Petitioner made several applications for government appointment without success.
Petitioner learnt of ban via memorandum (Annexure D): 'Government of India regret their inability to lift the ban on his employment for the present.'
Petition under Art. 226 to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi dismissed in limine on September 12, 1956; certificate for appeal refused on April 26, 1957.
Petition under Art. 32 filed on August 20, 1957.

Respondents' affidavit by G.P. Das: Central Tractor Organisation temporary; petitioner purely temporary hand, services terminated per Rule 5; ban is departmental instruction for guidance, does not prevent applying, applications considered on merits; no deprivation of right to apply; no show cause needed.
Affidavit erroneously claims special leave petition dismissed by Supreme Court on April 26, 1957 (no such petition filed).

legal_issues.text: Whether the ban on petitioner's employment in government service violates Article 16(1) right to equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.
Whether termination of temporary service under Rule 5 was proper and whether ban is merely a departmental instruction without legal effect.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ban discriminates against petitioner in government employment, depriving right to be considered on merits.
No opportunity to show cause against ban; arbitrary imposition denies equal opportunity.

respondent_arguments.text: Services terminated properly as temporary under Rule 5, no reasons or show cause required.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 5, Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949

respondent_arguments.text: No right to appointment; ban is departmental instruction for guidance, petitioner can apply and be considered on merits; no deprivation.
Petition misconceived after exhausting remedies; res judicata from High Court dismissal.

court_reasoning.text: Affidavit verbose, repetitive, inaccurate (false claim of special leave dismissal), misleading on ban; ignores Annexure D.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Remissness in affidavit cannot be overlooked.

court_reasoning.text: Ban exists and prevents consideration on merits; right under Art. 16(1) includes being considered fairly, not just applying.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ban deprives constitutional right; arbitrary without show cause or justification related to suitability.

court_reasoning.text: No proceeding giving opportunity to show cause; cannot say ban has just relation to suitability.

holdings.text: Ban against employment arbitrary, violates Art. 16(1); must be removed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; guarantees equality of opportunity in public employment; ban violates right to be considered on merits.

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Permits termination of temporary service with one month's notice/pay without reasons; applied to termination but does not justify ban.

outcome.summary: Petition allowed; direction issued to respondents to remove the ban against petitioner's entry into government service.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus or appropriate direction to remove ban.

key_quotes.text: The fundamental right guaranteed by the Constitution is not only to make an application for a post under the Government but the further right to be considered on merits for the post for which an application has been made.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: So long as the ban subsists, any application made by the petitioner for employment under the State is bound to be treated as wastepaper.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains practical effect of ban violating equality.
